questions.text:
Which of the following storage practices is appropriately matched with the corresponding cold chain level?

 


	
		
			
			Level
			
			
			Storage practice
			
		
		
			
			A. Subcenter
			
			
			Use walk-in cold rooms to store large quantities of vaccines.
			
		
		
			
			B. Primary Health Center
			
			
			Use small ice-lined refrigerators to store vaccines for up to one month.
			
		
		
			
			C. Community Health Center
			
			
			Store vaccines in vaccine carriers for daily use.
			
		
		
			
			D. State Level
			
			
			Use domestic refrigerators due to their large storage capacity.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Primary Health Center - Use small ice-lined refrigerators to store vaccines for up to one month

 

Explanation:

 

Cold Chain Level

Storage Equipment

Capacity

Storage Duration

Temperature Range

Subcenter/Village Level

(Option A)

Vaccine Carriers, Day Carriers

16-20 vials (vaccine carrier)

24-48 hours

+2°C to +8°C
 

Ice Packs

-

1-4 hours

+2°C to +8°C

Primary Health Center (PHC)
(Option B)

Small Ice-Lined Refrigerator (ILR)

Up to 140 liters

Up to 1 month

+2°C to +8°C
 

Small Deep Freezer (DF)

-

-

-15°C to -25°C

Community Health Center (CHC)/ Sub District Hospital/ District Hospital

(Option C)

Large Ice-Lined Refrigerator (ILR)

Up to 300 liters

Up to 1 month

+2°C to +8°C
 

Large Deep Freezer (DF)

-

-

-15°C to -25°C

State/National Level

(Option D)

Walk-In Cold Rooms

Large quantities

Up to 3 months

+2°C to +8°C
 

Walk-In Freezers

Large quantities

Long-term storage

-15°C to -25°C

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding vaccine disposal?

choices.text: Empty plastic syringes should be categorized as white
Empty vaccine vials should be categorized as blue
Expired vaccines should be categorized as red
A hub cutter is used to dispose of vaccine vials

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) The empty vaccine vials should be categorized as blue

Explanation:

Vaccine Disposal:

Type

Category

Disinfection done by

Plastic part of syringes

Red (option A)

Autoclaving followed by shredding

Expired Vaccine

Yellow (option C)

Returned to manufacturer for incineration at >1200°C

Empty/damaged vials

Blue (option B)

Detergent or sodium hypochlorite

 

Hub cutter (Option D): This device safely disposes of needles by cutting them off from syringes. This prevents reuse and reduces the risk of needle-stick injuries and infections.

questions.text: Which of the following can maintain vaccine temperatures for the longest duration?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Cold box

Explanation:

Different types of carriers:

 

 

Cold box

Vaccine carrier

Day carrier

Purpose

Supply vaccines to all peripheral centres

-Supply vaccines to outreach programs.

- Used in subcenters.

 

-Supply vaccines to nearby sessions.

-  Used in subcenters.

Capacity

50-75 vaccine vials

16-20 vaccine vials

6-8 vaccine vials

No. of ice packs placed

4-36

4

2

Maintains temperature of vaccine for

48-96 hours

24-48 hours

24-48 hours

Images

Vaccine carries and day carriers are used in Subcenters

 

Conditioned ice packs (Option D) are water packs frozen to -5°C to -20°C, then allowed to thaw to +2°C to +8°C to prevent vaccine freezing. They are used inside vaccine carriers or cold boxes to maintain the required temperature, but they do not provide long-term temperature maintenance on their own.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding ice packs?

choices.text: Plain water is used to prepare ice packs.
The entire volume of the ice pack can be filled with water.
Vials of DPT/TT should not be placed directly with the ice pack.
OPV vials should be placed with ice packs.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) The entire volume of the ice pack can be filled with water.

Explanation:

Ice packs:

  • Ice packs are frozen water packs that help carry out vaccinations at subcenters, village levels and outreach programs.
  • Ice packs are made up of only plain water with no salt (Option A)
  • The Ice pack should be filled up to a level marked on the side of it (Option B).
    • Filling the entire ice pack with water may damage the ice pack, as water expands on freezing.
  • Damaged ice packs/ice packs with any leakage should be discarded.
  • Freeze-sensitive vaccines such as Hep B, penta, and DPT/TT should not be placed in direct contact with the ice packs (Option C).
    • They should be placed in a carton/polythene bag and then placed with the ice packs.
  • OPV vials should be placed with ice packs since they are heat sensitive (Option D)

questions.text:
Match the following types of thermometers with their correct example:


	
		
			
			Term
			
			
			Example
			
		
		
			
			i) Dial Thermometer
			
			
			a) Monitors the temperature of the Deep freezer
			
		
		
			
			ii) Hygro Thermometer
			
			
			b) Monitors the temperature of the ILR
			
		
		
			
			iii) Steam Alcohol Thermometer
			
			
			c) Used to determine air humidity

choices.text: i) - b, ii) - c, iii) - a.
i) - c, ii) - a, iii) - b.
i) - a, ii) - b, iii) - c.
i) - c, ii) - b, iii) - a.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) i) - b, ii) - c, iii) - a.

Explanation:

Dial Thermometer

 
  • Tool to monitor the temperature inside Ice-Lined Refrigerators (ILRs).
  • They are important for ensuring vaccines are stored within the safe temperature range of +2°C to +8°C.

Hygro Thermometer

 
  • Measures both temperature and humidity.
  • Used in environments where both parameters are important, such as climate control and storage conditions.

Steam Alcohol Thermometer

 
  • These are used to monitor the temperature of Deep Freezers (DFs)

questions.text: The hospital management is deciding between procuring a large ILR (Ice-Lined Refrigerator) or a large deep freezer for vaccine storage due to frequent power outages in that area. Which of the following would be the most important factor to consider when making this decision?

choices.text: The difference in temperature ranges between the ILR and the deep freezer.
The equipment’s ability to maintain temperature during power outages.
The physical space available for installation of either piece of equipment.
The need to store ice packs for vaccine transportation.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) The equipment's ability to maintain temperature during power outages.

 

Explanation:

  • The scenario highlights a critical factor: Frequent power outages.
  • ILRs are designed for locations with unreliable electricity as the ice lining helps maintain safe temperatures longer than a deep freezer with no power.

 

Feature

Ice-Lined Refrigerator (ILR)

Deep Freezer (DF)

Purpose

Safe storage of vaccines at +2°C to +8°C, especially in areas with unreliable electricity.

Freezing ice packs and short-term storage of OPV at district level and above

Temperature Range

+2°C to +8°C

-15°C to -25°C

Power Failure

Maintains safe temperatures for at least 8 hours during outage

Limited hold-over time, dependent on the number of ice packs and frequency of opening

Vaccine Placement

The upper part stores freeze-sensitive vaccines (e.g., Hepatitis B, DPT), while the lower part stores heat-sensitive vaccines (e.g., OPV, BCG, Measles).

Never used to store vaccines. However, if used, using the same DF for vaccine storage and ice pack preparation is not recommended.

Monitoring

A dial thermometer is used to monitor the temperature twice daily.

A stem alcohol thermometer is used to monitor the temperature.

 

The image below shows ice-lined refrigerator.

The image below shows a deep freezer.

These considerations are secondary to ensuring vaccine viability in this scenario, with power failure being the major determiner.(Options A, C, and D)

questions.text: A nurse is preparing to administer a 0.1 ml dose of the BCG vaccine to a 6-month-old infant. Which type of syringe should the nurse use?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option A

Explanation:

To administer small volume liquids, tuberculin syringes are best suited as they are marked in ml.

Feature

Tuberculin syringe (Option A)

Insulin syringe (Option B)

Markings

Marked in millilitres (ml), typically from 0.1 ml to 1 ml.

Calibrated in units, typically from 10 to 100 units.

Used in

Used to measure and administer small volumes of liquid, such as IM injections, test for TB and allergies

Used specifically to administer insulin, which is dosed in units.

Image

  • To prevent medication errors, ensuring the correct syringe is crucial for accurate dosing, especially in infants.
  • Always verify the syringe type and calibration before preparing or administering any medication.
  • Tuberculin and insulin syringes cannot be used interchangeably.

questions.text: If a healthcare provider temporarily uses a domestic refrigerator to store vaccines, where should he place the Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV) and Measles vaccines inside the refrigerator?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Top shelf

Explanation:

Appropriate placement is essential to maintain the cold chain.

  • Heat-sensitive vaccines, such as OPV, BCG and Measles vaccines, are best stored on the top shelf, as they provide a more stable temperature and reduce the risk of freezing, which can occur in colder areas like the bottom shelf or door shelves.

Domestic Refrigerator Usage

Details

Vaccine Storage

Can be used for storing vaccines at private clinics and nursing homes, but hold-over time and capacity are limited. Requires a guaranteed continuous power supply.

Temperature Range

Maintains a cabinet temperature between +2°C to +8°C.

Placement of Vaccines
(Options A, B, C, D)
  • Top Shelf: Measles, BCG, Rotavirus vaccine, OPV
  • Middle Shelf: DPT, Pentavalent vaccine, TT, IPV, Hepatitis B, and diluents placed next to their corresponding vaccines.
  • Bottom Shelf: Water-filled ice packs to help maintain temperature stability.
  • Door: Avoid storing vaccines in the door as they experience the most temperature fluctuation

Ice Pack Usage

Place ice packs filled with water on the bottom shelf and in the refrigerator door to help maintain the temperature in case of a power outage.

Temperature Monitoring

A dial thermometer is placed inside the refrigerator to monitor the temperature twice daily.

questions.text: A vaccination campaign in a remote village with limited electricity access. Which of the following vaccines is most susceptible to damage if not properly maintained during transport?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV)

 

Explanation:

  • The scenario mentions a remote village, which indicates challenges in maintaining the cold chain during transport due to its limited electricity access.
  • OPV, being highly heat-sensitive, is most susceptible to damage.

Characteristics

Heat Sensitive Vaccines

Freeze Sensitive Vaccines

Definition

Vaccines that lose potency (effectiveness) when exposed to temperatures higher than their recommended storage temperature of +2°C to +8°C.

Vaccines that lose potency if frozen or stored below their recommended temperature of +2°C to +8°C.

Storage in ILR

Stored in the bottom of an Ice Lined Refrigerator (ILR), where the temperature is coldest.

Stored in the top of an Ice Lined Refrigerator (ILR), where the temperature is warmer.

Examples
  • Most heat sensitive: reconstituted BCG, OPV (Option C), Measles, Rotavirus, JE
  • Least heat sensitive: Pentavalent, PCV
  • Most freeze sensitive: Hepatitis B, Pentavalent, IPV, DPT (Option A, B and D)
  • Least freeze sensitive: TT, Td

questions.text: A 10-month-old infant came to the clinic for a regular follow-up visit. He missed his most recent vaccine, which was scheduled for 9 months. According to the National Immunization Schedule, which of the following vaccines is not administered to a 10-month-old infant?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) DPT

 

Explanation:

  • Measles Vaccine: Scheduled at 9 months as per the National Immunization Schedule (NIS) in India.

  • If missed, it should be administered as soon as possible.

  • Pneumococcal Conjugate Vaccine (PCV) Booster: Given at 9 months, and if missed, can still be administered at 10 months.

  • DPT Vaccine: The primary DPT series is given at 6, 10, and 14 weeks, and the first booster dose is scheduled at 16-24 months. Therefore, DPT is not given at 9 or 10 months.

 

National Immunization Schedule:

  • The National Immunization Schedule (NIS) in India provides a structured guideline for vaccination to protect children against various infectious diseases.
  • The schedule includes primary series, booster doses, and catch-up immunization strategies.
Age Vaccine
At Birth BCG, Hepatitis B (Birth dose), OPV (0 dose)
6 Weeks DPT-1, IPV-1, Hepatitis B-1, Hib-1, Rotavirus-1, PCV-1
10 Weeks DPT-2, IPV-2, Hepatitis B-2, Hib-2, Rotavirus-2, PCV-2
14 Weeks DPT-3, IPV-3, Hepatitis B-3, Hib-3, Rotavirus-3, PCV-3
6 Months Vitamin A (first dose)
9 Months Measles-1, PCV Booster, JE-1 (in endemic areas)
16-24 Months DPT Booster-1, IPV Booster, Measles-2, Vitamin A (second dose)
5-6 Years DPT Booster-2, OPV Booster
10 Years Tetanus and Diphtheria (Td)
16 Years Tetanus and Diphtheria (Td)

Catch-Up Immunization Strategy:

  • If a child misses a vaccine, they should receive it as soon as possible without restarting the series.

  • Measles and PCV vaccines, if missed at 9 months, can still be administered at 10 months.

  • DPT is not scheduled at 9 or 10 months but given in infancy (primary doses) and later as a booster at 16-24 months.

 

Measles (Option A): Incorrect because it is given at 9 months and may be administered if missed.

PCV (Option C): Incorrect; primary doses completed earlier; no routine dose scheduled exactly at 10 months.

None of the above (Option D): Incorrect because DPT is not scheduled at 10 months.

questions.text: A nurse is preparing to administer a 0.1 ml dose of the BCG vaccine to a 6-month-old infant. Which type of syringe should the nurse use?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Tuberculin syringe

 

Explanation:

 

Feature

Tuberculin syringe (Option A)

Insulin syringe (Option B)

Markings

Marked in millilitres (ml), typically from 0.1 ml to 1 ml.

Calibrated in units, typically from 10 to 100 units.

Used in

Used to measure and administer small volumes of liquid, such as IM injections, test for TB and allergies

Used specifically to administer insulin, which is dosed in units.

Image
  • To prevent medication errors, ensuring the correct syringe is crucial for accurate dosing, especially in infants.
  • Always verify the syringe type and calibration before preparing or administering any medication.
  • Tuberculin and insulin syringes cannot be used interchangeably.

questions.text: Which of the following vaccines is appropriate to administer to an 18-month-old child who has not received any prior vaccination according to national immunisation schedule?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: (A) OPV + MMR

  • OPV (Oral Polio Vaccine) and MMR (Measles, Mumps, Rubella) are administered up to 5 years of age in the catch-up vaccination schedule.

  • BCG is given only up to 1 year of age, so it is not recommended at 18 months.

  • Pentavalent (DPT, Hep B, Hib) is given up to 1 year of age and is not recommended after that.

Delayed Immunization Schedule

Time Vaccine
Till 15 days OPV birth dose
Till 24 hours Hepatitis B birth dose
Up to 1 year BCG, Rotavirus, Pentavalent, fIPV, PCV, Hepatitis B (alone)
Up to 5 years OPV, Measles, MR vaccine, Vitamin A drops
Up to 7 years DPT
Up to 15 years JE
Lifelong Td

Pentavalent (Option B): Incorrect because it is not given after 1 year of age.

BCG + OPV (Option C): Incorrect because BCG is not given after 1 year.

BCG + OPV + MMR (Option D): Incorrect because BCG is not given after 1 year.

questions.text: A 68 y/o man with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and hypertension hasn't received any vaccines in recent years and is concerned about his increased risk of infections. Which of the following vaccines should be given to him?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) All of the above

Explanation:

  • Influenza vaccine: Recommended annually for elderly individuals, especially those with chronic conditions like COPD, to prevent complications from influenza.

  • Pneumococcal vaccine (PCV13 followed by PPSV23): PCV13 is given first, followed by PPSV23 at least one year later, to provide protection against pneumococcal pneumonia, which is a major risk in elderly and COPD patients.

  • Tdap vaccine: A single dose is recommended in adulthood if not previously given, followed by Td boosters every 10 years. It provides protection against tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis.

Recommended Vaccines for Elderly Individuals

Vaccine Indication Schedule
Influenza Annual vaccination for all individuals ≥ 60 years 1 dose every year
Pneumococcal (PCV13, PPSV23) Prevents pneumococcal pneumonia, especially in chronic conditions PCV13 followed by PPSV23 after 1 year
Tdap/Td Tetanus, diphtheria, pertussis protection Tdap once, then Td booster every 10 years
Herpes Zoster (Zoster vaccine) Prevents shingles in adults ≥ 50 years 2 doses, 2–6 months apart

questions.text: A 30 y/o woman at 16 weeks gestation has a history of three prior pregnancies and her last delivery was 18 months ago. Which of the following is the most appropriate Td vaccination schedule for this patient?

choices.text: 2 doses of Td vaccine, one month apart, starting immediately.
1 dose of Td vaccine around the 7th month of pregnancy.
No Td vaccine is needed for this pregnancy.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 1 dose of Td vaccine around the 7th month of pregnancy.

 

Explanation:

  • This patient is considered a multigravida because she has a history of three prior pregnancies.
  • Her last delivery was less than 3 years ago (18 months).
  • Multigravidas, who last gave birth three years ago, should receive a booster dose of the Td vaccine around the seventh month of pregnancy.
  • The use of Td is recommended during pregnancy to protect against maternal and neonatal tetanus & diphtheria during prenatal care.

 

Primi-gravida or multigravida with last delivery >3 years ago

2 doses of Td vaccine:

  • Td1 - Early in pregnancy, 0.5ml IM
  • Td2 - 4 weeks after Td1, 0.5ml IM

Multigravida with last delivery <3 years
(If received 2 Td doses in a pregnancy within the last 3 yrs)

Td-Booster around the 7th month of pregnancy

Live-attenuated vaccines contain weakened forms of the virus or bacteria and pose a risk to the developing fetus thus they are avoided in pregnancy.

Examples

  • MMR (Measles, Mumps, Rubella)
  • Varicella (Chickenpox)
  • BCG (Bacillus Calmette-Guérin)
  • Yellow Fever

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding BCG vaccination?

choices.text: Can be administered only on the left upper arm
Provides protection only against extrapulmonary TB

questions.solution:
Correct Answera: C) Provides protection only against extrapulmonary TB

Explanation:

  • The BCG (Bacillus Calmette–Guérin) vaccine is primarily administered to prevent childhood tuberculosis, especially its severe forms.

  • Its most consistent and reliable protective effect is against extrapulmonary TB, particularly:

    • TB meningitis

    • Miliary TB

BCG Vaccine: 

Aspect Details
Full Form Bacillus Calmette-Guérin (BCG)
Type of Vaccine Live attenuated vaccine derived from Mycobacterium bovis
Mechanism of Action Stimulates cellular immunity (T-cell mediated) against Mycobacterium tuberculosis
Indications Routine childhood immunization (to prevent severe TB forms like miliary TB & TB meningitis)
High-risk individuals in endemic regions
Considered for health workers and individuals with high TB exposure
Administration Route: Intradermal (ID)
Site: Left upper arm (deltoid region) to standardize scar assessment
Schedule Given at birth (or as early as possible until 1 year of age if not previously vaccinated)
Dosage 0.1 mL for infants >1 month
0.05 mL for newborns (≤1 month)
Contraindications Symptomatic HIV/AIDS (due to risk of disseminated BCG infection)
Primary immunodeficiencies
Severe illness
Adverse Reactions Local ulceration and scar formation (normal immune response)
Suppurative lymphadenitis (rare)
Disseminated BCG infection (only in immunocompromised patients)
Scar Formation A characteristic BCG scar develops at the injection site within 6-8 weeks, confirming successful vaccination
Special Considerations Not part of adult vaccination schedules unless in specific high-risk settings
No booster doses required, as its protective effect does not increase with revaccination

It is an inactivated vaccine (Option A):
Incorrect because BCG is a live attenuated vaccine, not inactivated.

Can be administered only on the left upper arm (Option B):
Incorrect because the left upper arm is preferred for documentation and standardization, but not mandatory.

questions.text:
Match the following vaccines with their route of administration

 


	
		
			
			VACCINE
			
			
			ROUTE
			
		
		
			
			A) Rotavirus
			
			
			i) Subcutaneous
			
		
		
			
			B) BCG
			
			
			ii) Oral
			
		
		
			
			C) JE
			
			
			iii) Intramuscular
			
		
		
			
			D) Pentavalent
			
			
			iv) Intradermal
questions.solution:
Matching vaccines with their correct route of administration:

Vaccine Route of Administration
Rotavirus (A) Oral (ii) → Given as oral drops.
BCG (B) Intradermal (iv) → Given in the left upper arm.
Japanese Encephalitis (JE) (C) Subcutaneous (i) → Given in the upper arm.
Pentavalent (D) Intramuscular (iii) → Given in the anterolateral thigh.

 

Vaccine Administration Routes and Their Importance

Vaccines are administered through different routes based on their formulation and intended immune response. The choice of route ensures optimal immune activation while minimizing adverse effects. Below is a detailed breakdown of vaccines, their administration routes, doses, and sites:

Route Vaccine Dose Site
Oral OPV (Oral Polio Vaccine) 2 drops Oral
Rotavirus 5 drops Oral
Intradermal BCG (Bacillus Calmette-Guérin) 0.1 ml (0.05 ml until 1 month) Left upper arm
fIPV (Fractional IPV) 0.1 ml Right upper arm
Intramuscular Pentavalent (DPT, Hep B, Hib) 0.5 ml Antero-lateral side of mid-thigh
PCV (Pneumococcal Conjugate Vaccine) 0.5 ml Antero-lateral side of mid-thigh
Td (Tetanus and Diphtheria) 0.5 ml Upper arm
Subcutaneous MR (Measles-Rubella) 0.5 ml Right upper arm
JE (Japanese Encephalitis) 0.5 ml

Left upper arm (Live vaccine via S.C)

Killed vaccine via I.M- Anterolateral thigh (<3 years, IM); Deltoid (≥3 years, IM)
Intranasal Influenza 0.2 ml (0.1 ml each nostril) Nasopharynx

  • Oral vaccines (OPV, Rotavirus) stimulate gut immunity and are given as drops.

  • Intradermal vaccines (BCG, fIPV) create a localized immune response, essential for tuberculosis prevention (BCG).

  • Intramuscular vaccines (Pentavalent, PCV, Td) require deep penetration into the muscle to enhance systemic immunity.

  • Subcutaneous vaccines (MR, JE) are injected into fatty tissue to enable slower antigen release.

  • Intranasal vaccines (Influenza) mimic natural infection routes, triggering mucosal immunity.

questions.text: Under the Vitamin A distribution scheme, which of the following is the appropriate dose of Vitamin A to prevent blindness in a 3-year-old?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 200,000 IU

Explanation:

  • Vitamin A supplementation is essential to prevent blindness and reduce childhood mortality.

  • Under the National Vitamin A Prophylaxis Program, children aged 1 to 5 years receive 200,000 IU every 6 months as a preventive measure.

  • This dose is crucial for preventing xerophthalmia, night blindness, and severe infections associated with Vitamin A deficiency.

Vitamin A Supplementation Schedule in Children

Age Dosage (Oral Route)
< 6 months 50,000 IU
6 - 12 months 100,000 IU
9 months (with measles vaccine) 100,000 IU
1 - 5 years (every 6 months) 200,000 IU 

Treatment of Vitamin A Deficiency:

  • Oral 200,000 IU on 2 successive days

  • All children with corneal ulcers should receive Vitamin A, regardless of suspected deficiency.

100,000 IU (Option A): Incorrect. This dose is recommended only at 9 months, not for a 3-year-old.

150,000 IU (Option B): Incorrect. This is not a recommended standard dose.

50,000 IU (Option D): Incorrect. This is the dose for infants under 6 months, not a 3-year-old.

questions.text:
Consider the following statements:

i) f IPV is a live attenuated vaccine.

ii) fIPV is not effective in control of epidemics

iii) OPV has a shorter shelf life than IPV

iv) fIPV provides humoral immunity only

v) 5 ml of fIPV is administered via IM route

Which of the following are correct?
questions.solution:
• i) IPV is a live attenuated vaccine: Incorrect

    • IPV (Inactivated Poliovirus Vaccine) is a killed (inactivated) vaccine, not a live attenuated vaccine.

    • OPV (Oral Poliovirus Vaccine) is the live attenuated form.

  • ii) fIPV is not effective in control of epidemics: Correct

    • Fractional IPV (fIPV) is not ideal for rapid outbreak control because it does not induce sufficient mucosal immunity, which is required for halting poliovirus transmission.

    • OPV is preferred in epidemic situations due to its ability to induce gut immunity and stop transmission.

  • iii) OPV has a shorter shelf life than IPV: Correct

    • OPV is a live virus vaccine, requiring strict cold chain maintenance and has a shorter shelf life than IPV, which is inactivated and more stable.

  • iv) fIPV provides humoral immunity only: Correct

    • fIPV induces humoral (systemic) immunity but does not provide strong mucosal immunity in the intestines, which is necessary to prevent virus shedding.

    • OPV provides both humoral and mucosal immunity.

  • v) 5 ml of fIPV is administered via IM route: Incorrect

    • fIPV is given as 0.1 ml intradermally, not 5 ml intramuscularly.

    • The standard full-dose IPV (not fractional) is given intramuscularly (IM).

Differences Between IPV and OPV

Feature IPV (Inactivated Poliovirus Vaccine) OPV (Oral Poliovirus Vaccine)
Type of Vaccine Inactivated (killed) virus Live attenuated virus
Route of Administration Intramuscular (IM) or Intradermal (ID) Oral (drops)
Immunity Provided Systemic (humoral) immunity Systemic + mucosal immunity (gut immunity)
Effectiveness in Epidemics Not effective in stopping transmission Highly effective in epidemic control
Prevention of Virus Shedding Limited effect on intestinal virus shedding Strong gut immunity prevents shedding
Shelf Life & Storage More stable, longer shelf life Less stable, requires strict cold chain
Risk of Vaccine-Derived Poliovirus (VDPV) No risk of VDPV Small risk of VDPV due to live virus reversion
Use in Eradication Programs Primarily used in polio-free areas Used in endemic and outbreak settings

Schedule of OPV and fIPV

  • OPV Schedule: Administered at 6 weeks, 10 weeks, 14 weeks, 16–24 months, and 5 years (2 oral drops per dose).

  • fIPV (Fractional IPV) Schedule:

    • First and second doses at 6 weeks and 14 weeks (0.1 ml intradermally in the right upper arm).

    • Fractional dose: 1/5th of the total IPV dose.

    • From January 1, 2023, a third IPV dose has been introduced at 9 completed months (0.1 ml intradermally in the left upper arm, since MR vaccine is administered in the right upper arm).

Rationale for the Shift from OPV to IPV

  • OPV contains live, weakened poliovirus, which can mutate and cause vaccine-associated paralytic polio (VAPP) or lead to outbreaks due to vaccine-derived poliovirus (VDPV).

  • IPV contains inactivated poliovirus, eliminating these risks and making it safer for all populations, including immunocompromised individuals.

  • The shift helps maintain high immunity levels while supporting global polio eradication efforts without the risks of live-virus vaccines.
